metadata.synopsis: After Dr. Clint Reed (Richard Widmark) is called in to supervise an autopsy of a unknown man, he discovers that the John Doe died of pneumonic plague. Revealing his discovery to the mayor and city officials, Reed is informed that he has 48 hours before the public will be told about a potential outbreak. Joined by Captain Tom Warren (Paul Douglas) and his wife, Nancy (Barbara Bel Geddes), Reed must race against time to find out where the unknown man came from.

reviews: If you are n fingernail chewer, the excitement and suspense of this film will have you eating your nails down to the knuckle.

It is a blend of suspense and violence built around the 48-hour battle of the United States Public Health Service to forestall a pnumonic plague outbreak in a large city. It is the work of that master of melodrama, Elia Kazan, whose direction is expert.
The sets and staging are fantastic... Jack Palance notches a mesmerizing presence as a menace of the streets with a long reach and dubious morals.
An absorbing thriller about three fleeing killers who don't know that they are carrying the germs of the Black Death. Elia Kazan brilliantly directs a fine cast.
The ostensibly documentary approach veers into something more dreamlike.
It, too, uses social commentary but it's so expertly folded into the story, and so gripping, that it succeeds as both art and entertainment.
Superbly made look at scientists battling a contagious disease, with Widmark outstanding lead.
Still tense today, more than 60 years after it was made

A taut thriller with a poignant message, Panic in the Streets, which won the Oscar for Motion Picture Story, is well directed by Kazan and well acted by Richard Widmark, Jack Palance, Zero Mostell (just before he was blacklisted) and others.
This is a tense, offbeat, and fairly absorbing drama.
There is vivid action, nice human touches and some bizarre moments. Jack Palance gives a sharp performance.
Fine Elia Kazan drama with Richard Widmark.
A classy thriller, much less laden with significance than most Kazan movies.
Performances by Richard Widmark and Jack Palance and the New Orleans settings distinguish this not-quite-noir.
An underrated cracker.
This comparably early Elia Kazan movie indicates just how prodigious his talents behind the camera could be.
...[features] an action-packed finale that's surprisingly tense.
Benefits immeasurably from a menacing turn by Jack Palance.
Tense and pulpy.
Realistic medical noir thriller.
